title: Treasury yields reach 4%, then retreat, after Bank of England buys gilts
text:
* The yield on the 2-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD02Y fell by 6.6 basis points to 4.221%. Yields move in the opposite direction to prices.

* The yield on the 10-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD10Y retreated 1.4 basis points to 3.934%.

* The yield on the 30-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD30Y rose 2.3 basis points to 3.851%.

What's driving markets

The 10-year Treasury yield touched 4.010% in the early hours of Wednesday, its highest in 14 years, after a batch of U.S. economic reports came in stronger than forecast on Tuesday, reinforcing expectations that the Federal Reserve will persevere with its aggressive pace of interest rate hikes as it battles rampant inflation.

"Not helping matters for the Treasury market was a solid mix of US economic data [on Tuesday]… including a bounce in U.S. consumer confidence and a surprising surge in the volatile new home sales series," said Brian Daingerfield, head of G10 FX strategy at Nat West Markets.

Hal Cook, senior investment analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, noted that with the exception of Japan, most developed economy central banks "have raised rates simultaneously and consistently, with this trend expected to continue."

However, Treasury yields have fallen back in line with international peers – easing 16 basis points to 3.932% at one point – after the Bank of England stepped in to buygilts at "whatever scale is necessary" in order to calm febrile markets.

Investors had dumped U.K. government bonds in recent days in response to what they deemed a dangerously profligate budget by new finance minister Kwasi Kwarteng.

Ten-year gilt yields BX:TMBMKGB-10Y, which earlier on Wednesday had climbed above 4.6% for the first time plunged 36 basis points to 4.154%.

The BoE's move was welcomed by the fixed income market for adding liquidity.

"U.S. financial conditions have tightened sharply again, fueled not just by the Fed but by spillovers from U.K. markets," Goldman Sachs said in a note issued before the BoE's actions.

Indeed, traders have taken note of this recent tightening of market conditions and have pulled back the probability of a 75 basis point rate hike by the Fed at its November meeting from about 70% several days ago to 48% on Wednesday.

The Treasury on Wednesday will auction $36 billion of 7-year notes.
